Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Microwave Heating of Carbon Nanotube Coatings to Enable Rapid Welding in 3D-Printed Polymer Structures

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the most critical problems in additive manufacturing of plastic components is poor part strength caused by weak interfacial welding between the deposited polymer layers. Uniform heating of the manufactured part cannot solve this problem because it can cause warping of the 3D-printed structure that affects the mechanical reliability of three-dimensional (3D) printing as a plastic manufacturing technique. This research examines a novel manufacturing process where a thin coating of carbon nanotubes (CNTs) is deposited on the plastic filaments used in 3D printing. Microwave exposure of the printed parts causes the CNTs to heat that allows for localized polymer melting at the welds, resulting in markedly improved mechanical strength of the part. If successful, the additive manufacturing technology enabled by this project has the potential to overcome the current disparity between traditionally manufactured polymer parts such as injection molding, extrusion molding and machining as compared to parts printed with additive manufacturing techniques.

Specifically, this work uses a combination of experimentation and computation to measure and model the response of CNT-loaded polymer films in order to directly capture the coating thermal dynamics. This will be done using a combination of alternating current dielectric measurements, infrared imaging, and finite-element modeling (combining radio frequency heating and heat transfer in thin coatings). This will be followed by a scaled-up investigation of the coating, material extrusion, and controlled microwave exposure processes to demonstrate how this concept translates to an additive manufacturing context, with an emphasis on strength improvements (as measured on vertically printed tensile bars) and reliability. The microwave exposure will be carried out using simultaneous infrared imaging and real-time adjustment of forward power to yield consistent, specified heating treatments. The intellectual significance of the work stems from the translation of microscale CNT heating to processing-structure-property relationships for welds in complex, macroscale 3D printed structures. This work will have a strong impact on multiple scientific and engineering fields including polymer physics, nanomaterial percolation, microwave physics, plastics processing, advanced manufacturing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant aims to develop the science of nanocomposite interactions with microwave and RF fields in the context of thermoplastic additive manufacturing of strong, conductive parts. A major challenge in additive manufacturing of plastic parts is the weak interfacial welding between the deposited polymer layers. In this project, novel methods were developed to overcome this key challenge by harnessing the responsiveness of carbon nanotubes to radio frequency (RF) and microwave energy. A novel manufacturing process was invented where a thin coating of a polymer solution containing the proper concentration of carbon nanotubes is deposited on plastic filaments to produce a new type of filament for 3D printing. The new filament enables strong interfacial bonding between successively printed layers upon irradiation with RF or microwave energy. The fracture strength of the resulting welds approached those made with traditional manufacturing techniques such as injection molding.

In this research project, the central concept of carbon nanotubes’ strong response to microwave fields was investigated in composite films and coatings. This work involved multiphysics modeling, microwave dielectric characterization, experimentation, and thermal imaging. Multiphysics modeling involved coupling electromagnetic solutions with heat transfer analysis. For RF/microwave dielectric characterization, methods were developed to measure the dielectric properties of samples loaded with nanoparticles versus frequency and temperature. Thermal imaging was used to monitor the heat distribution throughout the sample during exposure to RF/microwave energy. The relationship between the nanofiller loading and the heating response was non-monotonic.

This award resulted in significant technology transition and commercialization success. The developed technology was licensed to a small company (Essentium) for commercialization. In addition to the RF and microwave irradiation methods, the company and the university teams partnered together to develop a in-situ electromagnetic field fixture attached to a 3D printer nozzle. This field welds the 3D-printed part together during the printing process. The resulting mechanical properties are competitive with injection molded parts, which is one of the longstanding challenges in the additive manufacturing community. Furthermore, a broad range of electromagnetic susceptor materials were investigated in addition to carbon nanotubes, including carbon fiber and new nanomaterials such as laser-induced graphene and submicron composite fibers made using electrospinning.

This award produced multiple peer-reviewed publications, conference presentations, and invited presentations. Multiple graduate students and many undergraduate researchers were supported by this grant. The lead graduate student was remarkably successful in connecting the fundamental scientific findings with entrepreneurial and industrial applications.

 


Last Modified: 09/25/2020
Modified by: Mohammad Saed
